moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e: Not overly familiar with the Sicilian, not keen on this move as it breaks the rule of moving the same piece twice in the opening.
moves.5... Nf6 6. Bd3: Protects, but is this where bishops belong?  No!
moves.6... d5 7. Bb5: exd5 would be better, this move could lead to Qa5 , Nc3 d4
moves.9... Nxe4 10. Re1: Hoping to get some kind of pin, however I was fealing very undeveloped at this stage, space count, white = 4 black = 12!!
moves.10... Be7 11. Nxe5: Ok, I took over a minute on this move, sure that I could win the knight on e4 with a pin (Qxe5, f3).  It turns out I did win it, but Fritz found a way for it to be saved!  So this move got a '?' in analysis, at least it wasn't '??'
moves.12... Bc5+ 13. Be3 Bxe3+ 14. Rxe3 O-O 15: I think that fxe4 could be played immediately here, however at the time I thought that b2 and a1 might fall, however I don't think this is the case, fxe4 Qxb2, Nc3 d4, Rb1 Qe3, Qxd4 might be one way around this
Now here I was expecting a trade of queens (or Fritz's g5 seems even stronger), to which I think black would have won, however I was pleased to see the next move which enabled me to execute my plan and the game swings into white as the favourite
moves.23. Qxf4: Only reply is to capture back, isn't it?  The defender to e8 IS f8!
moves.23... Rxf4: Which now means that d3 can be munched by the rook on e3.  the pawn on e4 is then pinned.  My palms were less sweaty by this stage ;)
moves.24... exd3 25. Rxe8+ Kf7 26. Ra8: Black resigns as pawns will fall and his passed pawn on d3 poses no real threat.  Hope you enjoyed my annotation.
